ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:0.5_0: The training rule on asking for rice and bean curry
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:1.2_0: the monks from the group of six ate rice and bean curry that they themselves had asked for.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:1.3_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:1.4_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics eat rice and bean curry that they themselves have asked for?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:1.7_0: The monks heard the complaints of those people
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:1.8_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:1.9_0: “How can the monks from the group of six do this?” ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:1.10_0: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:1.13_0: “... Foolish men, how can you do this?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:1.14_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...” ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:1.15_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:1.16.1_0: ‘“I will not ask for bean curry or rice for myself and then eat it,” this is how you should train.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:1.17_0: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:2.1_0: At one time a number of monks were sick.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:2.2_0: The monks who were looking after them asked,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:2.3_0: “We hope you’re bearing up, we hope you’re comfortable?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:2.4_0: “Previously we ate rice and bean curry that we ourselves had asked for, and then we were comfortable.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:2.6_0: Knowing that the Buddha had prohibited this, we don’t ask because we’re afraid of wrongdoing. And because of that we’re not comfortable.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:2.7_0: They told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Devadatta:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:2.8_0: “Monks, I allow a sick monk to eat rice and bean curry that he himself has asked for.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:2.9_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:2.10.1_0: ‘“When not sick, I will not ask for bean curry or rice for myself and then eat it,” this is how you should train.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:2.11_0: when not sick, he should not ask for bean curry and rice for himself and then eat it;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:2.12_0: If a monk who is not sick, out of disrespect, eats bean curry or rice that he himself has asked for, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:2.13.1_0: there is no offense for him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:2.15_0: To give rise to the robe.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:2.20_0: if it is built for someone else;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:2.21_0: if it is by means of her own property;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:2.24_0: if he is the first offender.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk37:2.25_0: The seventh training rule is finished.
